title: 114_hr1466
content: The "Surveillance State Repeal Act" repeals the USA PATRIOT Act and the FISA Amendments Act of 2008, requiring the destruction of certain information collected under these acts. SEC. 3 of the "Surveillance State Repeal Act" repeals the FISA Amendments Act of 2008, restoring previous laws. Certain information collected under section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act must be destroyed. SEC. 4 addresses terms of judges on the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to increase the maximum term from seven to ten years and remove the restriction on reappointment. Special Masters with technological expertise can now be appointed to advise courts on technical issues during proceedings. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to allow electronic surveillance of specified persons without regard to specific devices. Additionally, provisions for collections under the Act are enhanced. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to require a valid warrant based on probable cause for acquiring information related to a United States person. Additionally, the table of contents and provisions for electronic surveillance under the Act are updated. SEC. 7 prohibits the Federal Government from mandating backdoor access to encryption on electronic devices. SEC. 8 requires annual evaluations of government compliance with the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. SEC. 9 addresses whistleblower complaints. Employees or contractors in the intelligence community can report complaints about programs authorized by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act to various entities. The Comptroller General will investigate these complaints and submit a report to Congress. The term "covered complaint" refers to a complaint related to programs authorized by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act that indicates a violation of laws, rules, or regulations, gross mismanagement, waste of funds, abuse of authority, or a danger to public health or safety. SEC. 10. PROHIBITION ON INTERFERENCE WITH REPORTING OF WASTE, FRAUD, ABUSE, OR CRIMINAL BEHAVIOR. In General, no officer or employee of the intelligence community can retaliate against someone who discloses covered information to specific entities. Violators may face administrative sanctions, including termination. Covered information is defined in this section. The term "covered information" includes any information believed to show a violation of laws or mismanagement, waste of funds, abuse of authority, or danger to public health. The term "intelligence community" refers to the entities defined in the National Security Act of 1947. Prohibition of targeting US persons under Executive Order 12333 without a warrant. Prohibition on targeting US persons under Executive Order 12333 without a warrant, requiring annual audits for compliance and destruction of information collected without a valid warrant. The Act prohibits collecting information under Executive Order 12333 without a valid warrant for a US person not related to an ongoing investigation.
